com.ibm.xmi.framework
Class UML2Java

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.ibm.xmi.framework.UML2Java
public class UML2Java
extends java.lang.Object

This class generates Java classes, and optionally, interfaces and packages, from a UML 1.1 model in an XMI 1.0 file.

For each class in the UML model, a Java class is generated. The methods in the Java class are generated based on the attributes of the UML class and the association ends for the UML class.

The Java classes that are generated are subclasses of the XMIObjectImpl framework class. For each UML attribute, a get and set accessor method is generated for the corresponding Java class. The names of the methods are based on the names of the UML attributes.

For each UML association end that is navigable, there are three methods in the corresponding Java class: add, remove, and get. The names of the methods are based on the names of the UML association ends.

This class also generates a UserFactory class. The UserFactory class contains a method that lets you get a framework Model corresponding to the UML model, and it overrides the makeXMIObject method in the FactoryAdapter class so the framework will make instances of the generated Java classes rather than just XMIObjectImpls when XMI files are loaded.

The generated Java classes manipulate Framework Value objects; if you program with the generated Java classes, you do not need to deal with XMI names, the classes will handle them.

If your UML model contains multiple inheritance, you should use the -interfaces option so a Java interface and a Java class that implements the interface is generated for each UML class. The Java interfaces extend each other, and Java allows an interface to extend multiple interfaces. The generated Java classes that implement the interfaces don't inherit from each other, since that is not legal in Java.

The interfaces in the Data hierarchy were modified from the previous version of the framework to try to avoid name conflicts with methods in generated Java classes. Most of the methods in the framework that could have caused a name conflict have the letters "XMI" in them, so the chance of a name conflict between methods in the framework and methods in the generated Java classes is reduced, although not completely eliminated.

The generated Java classes should work with both XMI 1.0 and XMI 1.1.

If the names in the UML model are not legal names, or there are name conflicts, the generated code may not compile.

Method Detail

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
Process command line options and invoke the makeJava method for a UML2Java object.

makeJava

public void makeJava(java.lang.String directory,
                     java.lang.String topPackage,
                     java.util.Vector decls)
Generate Java code based on the directory, topPackage, interfaces, and declarations. If interfaces is true, generate an interface and implementation class for each class in the model; otherwise, just generate an implementation class. Then generate a UserFactory class so the framework will instantiate the generated classes during load.

setInterfaces

public void setInterfaces(boolean value)
Set interfaces
